label: lem-wasserstein-decomposition
title: Decomposition of the Hypocoercive Wasserstein Distance
nl_statement: The squared hypocoercive Wasserstein distance between two empirical measures μ₁ and μ₂ decomposes exactly into the sum of location and structural error components.

conclusion.text: W_h^2(μ₁, μ₂) = V_loc + V_struct

variables.name: μ₁
variables.description: Empirical measure of the first swarm

variables.name: μ₂
variables.description: Empirical measure of the second swarm

variables.name: W_h
variables.description: Hypocoercive Wasserstein distance

variables.name: V_loc
variables.description: Location error component

variables.name: V_struct
variables.description: Structural error component

implicit_assumptions.text: μ₁ and μ₂ are probability measures on a space where the hypocoercive Wasserstein distance is defined
V_loc and V_struct are the distances between centers of mass and centered shapes, respectively

label: lem-sx-implies-variance
title: Structural Positional Error and Internal Variance
nl_statement: The positional component of the structural error between the alive-walker distributions of two swarms is at most twice the sum of their physical internal positional variances of alive walkers.

equations.latex: V_{\text{x,struct}} \text{ as the positional component of the structural error between the two swarms' alive-walker distributions}
\text{Var}_k(x) := \frac{1}{k_{\text{alive}}} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{A}(S_k)} \|\delta_{x,k,i}\|^2 \text{ as the physical internal positional variance of the alive walkers in swarm } k

hypotheses.text: Let $k_1 := |\mathcal{A}(S_1)|$ and $k_2 := |\mathcal{A}(S_2)|$ denote the numbers of alive walkers in each swarm.
$V_{\text{x,struct}}$ is the positional component of the structural error between the two swarms' alive-walker distributions.
hypotheses.latex: V_{\text{x,struct}} \text{ as the positional component of the structural error between the two swarms' alive-walker distributions}

hypotheses.text: $\text{Var}_k(x) := \frac{1}{k_{\text{alive}}} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{A}(S_k)} \|\delta_{x,k,i}\|^2$ is the physical internal positional variance of the alive walkers in swarm $k$ (distinct from the $N$-normalized Lyapunov variance component $V_{\text{Var},x}$).

conclusion.text: $V_{\text{x,struct}} \le 2(\text{Var}_1(x) + \text{Var}_2(x))$

variables.name: number of alive walkers in swarm 1
variables.description: Size of the alive set in swarm 1

variables.name: number of alive walkers in swarm 2
variables.description: Size of the alive set in swarm 2

variables.name: positional structural error
variables.description: Positional component of the structural error between alive-walker distributions

variables.name: internal positional variance for swarm k
variables.description: k_alive-normalized variance of positions of alive walkers in swarm k

variables.name: internal positional variance for swarm 1
variables.description: Variance for alive walkers in swarm 1

variables.name: internal positional variance for swarm 2
variables.description: Variance for alive walkers in swarm 2

variables.name: position deviation for walker i in swarm k
variables.description: Position vector of alive walker i relative to center or reference

implicit_assumptions.text: Swarms $S_1$ and $S_2$ are defined with alive walker sets $\mathcal{A}(S_k)$ non-empty.
The norm $\|| \cdot \||$ is the Euclidean norm on positions.
The structural error is defined such that its positional component measures mismatch in alive-walker distributions.
Variances are computed with respect to a common reference frame for positions.

label: lem-greedy-preserves-signal
title: Greedy Pairing Guarantees Signal Separation
nl_statement: In a swarm state with high internal variance where alive walkers are partitioned into high-error and low-error sets, the sequential stochastic greedy pairing operator guarantees statistical separation in expected raw phase-space distances: large for high-error walkers and small for low-error walkers, with epsilon-dependent bounds.

equations.latex: \mathbb{E}[d_j \mid S_t, j \in L_k] \le R_L(\epsilon) + D_{\mathrm{valid}} \cdot c_k \exp\left(-\frac{D_H(\epsilon)^2 - R_L(\epsilon)^2}{2\epsilon^2}\right)

hypotheses.text: A swarm is in a state with high internal variance.
Its alive walkers $A_k$ are partitioned into a high-error set $H_k$ and a low-error set $L_k$ as per def-geometric-partition.

conclusion.text: The Sequential Stochastic Greedy Pairing Operator guarantees statistical separation in expected raw phase-space distance measurements: (1) For high-error walkers $i \in H_k$, $\mathbb{E}[d_i \mid S_t, i \in H_k] \ge D_H(\epsilon)$; (2) For low-error walkers $j \in L_k$, $\mathbb{E}[d_j \mid S_t, j \in L_k] \le R_L(\epsilon) + D_{\mathrm{valid}} \cdot c_k \exp\left(-\frac{D_H(\epsilon)^2 - R_L(\epsilon)^2}{2\epsilon^2}\right)$, with N-uniform, $\varepsilon$-dependent bounds.

variables.name: alive walkers
variables.description: Set of alive walkers in the swarm at iteration k.

variables.name: high-error set
variables.description: Partition of alive walkers with high error.

variables.name: low-error set
variables.description: Partition of alive walkers with low error.

variables.name: state
variables.description: Swarm state at time t.

variables.name: epsilon
variables.description: Noise or error parameter.

variables.name: high distance bound
variables.description: Lower bound on expected distance for high-error walkers, dependent on epsilon.

variables.name: low radius bound
variables.description: Upper bound related to low-error set radius, dependent on epsilon.

variables.name: valid distance
variables.description: Nominal valid pairing distance.

variables.name: constant
variables.description: Iteration-dependent constant for the exponential term.

variables.name: raw distance i
variables.description: Raw phase-space distance for walker i.

variables.name: raw distance j
variables.description: Raw phase-space distance for walker j.

implicit_assumptions.text: The partition into H_k and L_k is well-defined based on geometric criteria from def-geometric-partition.
The swarm state has sufficiently high internal variance to enable separation.
Distances are measured in phase-space with Gaussian noise of variance epsilon^2.

label: lem-patching-properties
title: Properties of the Patching Function
nl_statement: Properties of the patching function.

label: lem-compact-support-z-scores
title: Compact Support of Standardized Scores
nl_statement: The standardized scores have compact support.

label: lem-logistic-properties
title: Verification of Axiomatic Properties
nl_statement: Verification of axiomatic properties for the logistic model.

label: lem-potential-bounds
title: Uniform Bounds of the Fitness Potential
nl_statement: Any non-zero fitness potential \(V_i\) generated by this pipeline is uniformly bounded within a compact interval \([V_{\text{pot,min}}, V_{\text{pot,max}}]\), where the bounds are state-independent constants defined by the algorithmic parameters, with \(V_{\text{pot,min}} := \eta^{\alpha+\beta}\).

hypotheses.text: V_i is a non-zero fitness potential generated by the pipeline

conclusion.text: V_i is uniformly bounded within [V_{\text{pot,min}}, V_{\text{pot,max}}], where the bounds are state-independent constants defined by algorithmic parameters

variables.name: fitness potential
variables.description: Non-zero fitness potential value generated by the pipeline

variables.name: minimum potential bound
variables.description: State-independent lower bound for fitness potentials

variables.name: maximum potential bound
variables.description: State-independent upper bound for fitness potentials

variables.name: eta parameter
variables.description: Algorithmic parameter used in bound definition

variables.name: alpha parameter
variables.description: Algorithmic parameter used in bound definition

variables.name: beta parameter
variables.description: Algorithmic parameter used in bound definition

implicit_assumptions.text: Algorithmic parameters \eta, \alpha, \beta are positive real numbers ensuring a compact interval
The pipeline generates fitness potentials V_i based on these parameters
V_{\text{pot,max}} is defined analogously to V_{\text{pot,min}} elsewhere

label: lem-V_Varx-implies-variance
title: Large $V_{\text{Var},x}$ Implies Large Single-Swarm Positional Variance
nl_statement: If the total intra-swarm positional variance component $V_{\text{Var},x}(S_1, S_2)$ exceeds the threshold $R_{\text{total_var},x}^2 > 0$, then at least one of the two swarms has an intra-swarm positional variance exceeding half that threshold.

hypotheses.text: $V_{\text{Var},x}(S_1, S_2) > R_{\text{total_var},x}^2$ for some $R_{\text{total_var},x}^2 > 0$

conclusion.text: At least one swarm $k \in \{1, 2\}$ satisfies $\frac{1}{N} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{A}(S_k)} \|\delta_{x,k,i}\|^2 > \frac{R_{\text{total_var},x}^2}{2}$

variables.name: Swarm 1
variables.description: The first swarm of agents

variables.name: Swarm 2
variables.description: The second swarm of agents

variables.name: Number of agents per swarm
variables.description: The size of each swarm

variables.name: Positional deviation
variables.description: The positional deviation of agent i in swarm k from the swarm mean

variables.name: Total variance threshold
variables.description: A positive threshold for the total variance

variables.name: Intra-swarm positional variance component
variables.description: The variance term in the synergistic Lyapunov function

implicit_assumptions.text: Each swarm has exactly N agents, i.e., $|\mathcal{A}(S_1)| = |\mathcal{A}(S_2)| = N$
Positional deviations $\delta_{x,k,i}$ are computed relative to the mean position of each swarm

label: lem-phase-space-packing
title: The Phase-Space Packing Lemma
nl_statement: For a swarm of k ≥ 2 walkers in a compact phase-space domain, the fraction of close pairs under the algorithmic distance is bounded above by a monotonically decreasing function of the swarm's total hypocoercive variance, assuming λ_v ≤ λ_alg.

hypotheses.text: Swarm S_k consists of k ≥ 2 walkers with phase-space states {(x_i, v_i)} in a compact domain
Proximity threshold d_close > 0 is chosen
λ_v ≤ λ_alg
D_x and D_v are the spatial and velocity domain diameters

conclusion.text: There exists a continuous, monotonically decreasing function g such that f_close ≤ g(Var_h(S_k)) = (D_valid^2 - 2 Var_h(S_k)) / (D_valid^2 - d_close^2)

variables.name: number of walkers
variables.description: Size of the swarm

variables.name: position of walker i
variables.description: Spatial coordinate in phase space
constraints: within compact domain of diameter D_x

variables.name: velocity of walker i
variables.description: Velocity coordinate in phase space
constraints: within compact domain of diameter D_v

variables.name: proximity threshold
variables.description: Threshold for close pairs under d_alg

variables.name: velocity scaling in hypocoercive variance
variables.description: Weight for velocity variance

variables.name: velocity scaling in algorithmic distance
variables.description: Weight for velocity in d_alg

variables.name: spatial domain diameter
variables.description: Diameter of the position domain

variables.name: velocity domain diameter
variables.description: Diameter of the velocity domain

implicit_assumptions.text: Var_x(S_k) and Var_v(S_k) are well-defined variances of positions and velocities
The domain is compact, ensuring finite diameters D_x and D_v
d_alg defines a metric on phase space

label: lem-var-x-implies-var-h
title: Positional Variance as a Lower Bound for Hypocoercive Variance
nl_statement: For any swarm k, the total hypocoercive variance Var_h(S_k) is bounded below by the positional variance Var_x(S_k).

hypotheses.text: For any swarm k

conclusion.text: Var_h(S_k) ≥ Var_x(S_k)

variables.name: swarm index
variables.description: Index labeling a specific swarm.

variables.name: swarm k
variables.description: The k-th swarm configuration.

variables.name: hypocoercive variance
variables.description: Total hypocoercive variance function.

variables.name: positional variance
variables.description: Positional variance component.

implicit_assumptions.text: Var_h and Var_x are defined non-negative variance measures for swarms.

label: lem-outlier-fraction-lower-bound
title: N-Uniform Lower Bound on the Outlier Fraction
nl_statement: For a swarm with k >= 2 alive walkers, if the hypocoercive variance Var_h(S_k) exceeds R_h^2 > 0, then the fraction of alive walkers in the global kinematic outlier set O_k is at least (1 - ε_O) R_h^2 / D_h^2 > 0, independent of N.

hypotheses.text: Swarm k has k >= 2 alive walkers.
Structural parameter ε_O ∈ (0, 1).
Hypocoercive variance Var_h(S_k) > R_h^2 for some R_h^2 > 0.

conclusion.text: The fraction of alive walkers in the outlier set is bounded below: |O_k|/k >= (1 - ε_O) R_h^2 / D_h^2 =: f_O > 0, independent of N.

variables.name: global kinematic outlier set
variables.description: Set of outliers for swarm k.

variables.name: number of alive walkers
variables.description: Size of the swarm.

variables.name: structural parameter
variables.description: Parameter for outlier set definition.

variables.name: hypocoercive variance
variables.description: Internal variance measure for swarm S_k.

variables.name: variance threshold
variables.description: Positive threshold for large variance.

variables.name: hypocoercive diameter
variables.description: Scaling factor in the bound.

variables.name: outlier fraction lower bound
variables.description: Positive constant independent of N.

implicit_assumptions.text: D_h^2 > 0 is a fixed positive constant from the model.
The outlier set O_k is defined using ε_O and kinematic properties as per Section 6.3.
The hypocoercive variance relates to phase-space measures.

label: lem-outlier-cluster-fraction-lower-bound
title: N-Uniform Lower Bound on the Outlier-Cluster Fraction
nl_statement: In the local-interaction regime, using the clustering-based definition of the high-error set with maximum cluster diameter \(D_{\text{diam}}(\varepsilon) = c_d \cdot \varepsilon\) where \(c_d \varepsilon < 2\sqrt{R^2_{\text{var}}}\), if the swarm's internal positional variance satisfies \(\mathrm{Var}_x(S_k) > R^2_{\text{var}}\), then the fraction of alive walkers in the high-error set \(H_k(\varepsilon)\) is bounded below by a positive constant \(f_H(\varepsilon) > 0\) independent of \(N\) and \(k\).

variables.name: epsilon
variables.description: Error threshold parameter.

variables.name: k
variables.description: Number of walkers in the swarm subset \(S_k\).

variables.name: high-error set
variables.description: Set of walkers in high-error clusters based on phase-space clustering.

variables.name: c_d
variables.description: Fixed positive constant scaling the cluster diameter.

variables.name: variance threshold
variables.description: Threshold for internal positional variance.

variables.name: swarm subset
variables.description: Subset of k walkers in the swarm.

variables.name: positional variance
variables.description: Internal positional variance of the swarm subset \(S_k\).

variables.name: lower bound constant
variables.description: Positive constant bounding the high-error fraction, independent of N and k.

implicit_assumptions.text: The swarm consists of alive walkers.
N represents a large system size, uniform across bounds.
The phase-space clustering approach is well-defined in the local-interaction regime.

label: lem-geometric-separation-of-partition
title: Geometric Separation of the Partition
nl_statement: Under large positional variance Var(x) > R_var², the high-error set H_k(ε) and low-error set L_k(ε) for swarm k are geometrically separated in algorithmic phase space by D_H(ε) > R_L(ε) > 0, with low-error walkers forming clusters of size at least f_c k within radius R_L(ε).

hypotheses.text: H_k(ε) and L_k(ε) are the unified high-error and low-error sets for swarm k as defined in def-unified-high-low-error-sets
The swarm's internal positional variance is large: Var(x) > R_var²

conclusion.text: There exist N-uniform, ε-dependent constants D_H(ε) > R_L(ε) > 0 and a fractional constant f_c > 0 such that: (1) for any i ∈ H_k(ε) and j ∈ L_k(ε), d_alg(i, j) ≥ D_H(ε); (2) for any j ∈ L_k(ε), there exists C_j ⊂ L_k(ε) \ {j} with |C_j| ≥ f_c k and d_alg(j, ℓ) ≤ R_L(ε) for all ℓ ∈ C_j. The separation D_H(ε) > R_L(ε) ensures non-overlapping geometric signatures in algorithmic phase space.

variables.name: H_k(ε)
variables.description: Unified high-error set for swarm k

variables.name: L_k(ε)
variables.description: Unified low-error set for swarm k

variables.name: ε
variables.description: Error threshold parameter

variables.name: k
variables.description: Swarm index or size

variables.name: D_H(ε)
variables.description: Lower bound constant for separation between high and low-error sets

variables.name: R_L(ε)
variables.description: Upper bound radius for low-error clustering

variables.name: f_c
variables.description: Fractional constant for minimum cluster size

variables.name: d_alg
variables.description: Algorithmic distance metric

variables.name: R_var
variables.description: Variance threshold radius

variables.name: C_j
variables.description: Companion subset for low-error walker j

implicit_assumptions.text: Constants D_H(ε) and R_L(ε) are N-uniform and ε-dependent
f_c is a positive fractional constant independent of ε and N
Swarm consists of N walkers with positional variance defined
Algorithmic phase space is well-defined for distance metric d_alg

label: lem-variance-to-gap
title: From Bounded Variance to a Guaranteed Gap
nl_statement: For a set of at least two real numbers with empirical variance bounded below by a positive constant κ, the maximum absolute difference between any two numbers is at least √(2κ).

conclusion.text: There exists at least one pair of indices $(i, j)$ such that the maximum gap is bounded below: $\max_{i,j} |v_i - v_j| \ge \sqrt{2\kappa}$

variables.name: number of elements
variables.description: The number of real numbers in the set, an integer at least 2.

variables.name: set values
variables.description: The real numbers in the set, indexed from 1 to k.

variables.name: variance lower bound
variables.description: A strictly positive constant bounding the empirical variance from below.

implicit_assumptions.text: The empirical variance is defined as $\frac{1}{k} \sum_{i=1}^k (v_i - \bar{v})^2$, where $\bar{v}$ is the mean.

label: lem-rescale-derivative-lower-bound
title: Positive Derivative Bound for the Rescale Function
nl_statement: The first derivative of the canonical logistic rescale function g_A(z) is uniformly bounded below by a strictly positive constant g'_min over the operational range Z_supp.

conclusion.text: there exists a constant g'_{\min} > 0 such that \inf_{z \in Z_{\mathrm{supp}}} g'_A(z) = g'_{\min} > 0

variables.name: first derivative of rescale function
variables.description: derivative of the canonical logistic rescale function g_A

variables.name: z-score
variables.description: input variable in the operational range

variables.name: operational range
variables.description: domain of z-scores where g_A operates

variables.name: minimum derivative bound
variables.description: strictly positive lower bound for g'_A(z)

implicit_assumptions.text: The canonical logistic rescale function g_A is differentiable on Z_supp
Z_supp is a non-empty interval where g_A is defined and operational
g_A is the canonical logistic function used for rescaling

label: lem-raw-gap-to-rescaled-gap
title: From Raw Measurement Gap to Rescaled Value Gap
nl_statement: For fixed system parameters and any swarm state S with k ≥ 2 alive walkers, if raw measurement values have a gap |v_a - v_b| ≥ κ_raw > 0, then rescaled values have |g_A(z_a) - g_A(z_b)| ≥ κ_rescaled(κ_raw) > 0, where κ_rescaled(κ_raw) = (g'_min / σ'_max) ⋅ κ_raw is independent of S and k.

hypotheses.text: System parameters are fixed.
Swarm state S has k ≥ 2 alive walkers.
Raw measurement gap |v_a - v_b| ≥ κ_raw > 0.

conclusion.text: Rescaled value gap |g_A(z_a) - g_A(z_b)| ≥ κ_rescaled(κ_raw) > 0 with κ_rescaled independent of S and k.

variables.name: raw gap threshold
variables.description: Positive threshold for raw measurement gap.

variables.name: rescaled gap function
variables.description: Function mapping raw gap to guaranteed rescaled gap.

variables.name: number of alive walkers
variables.description: Size of swarm state with alive agents.

variables.name: swarm state
variables.description: State of the walker swarm.

variables.name: raw measurements
variables.description: Raw measurement values for agents a and b.

variables.name: rescaled positions
variables.description: Rescaled positions corresponding to measurements.

variables.name: rescaling function
variables.description: Function g_A applied to rescaled positions.

variables.name: minimum derivative of g
variables.description: Uniform lower bound on derivative of rescaling function.

variables.name: maximum derivative of sigma
variables.description: Uniform upper bound on derivative of sigma function.

implicit_assumptions.text: Uniform bounds g'_min and σ'_max on pipeline components exist and are positive.
Rescaling pipeline transforms raw measurements v to rescaled positions z via invertible functions.

label: lem-variance-to-mean-separation
title: From Total Variance to Mean Separation
nl_statement: A set of real numbers in a compact interval with sufficiently large empirical variance, when partitioned into two substantial non-empty subsets, guarantees a statistically significant separation between the subset means, bounded below by an expression involving the variance and maximum possible variance.

hypotheses.text: Set $\mathcal{V} = \{v_i\}_{i=1}^k$ with $k \ge 2$ real numbers, each $v_i \in [V_{\min}, V_{\max}]$ (compact interval).
$\mathcal{V}$ partitioned into disjoint non-empty subsets $H$ and $L$ with means $\mu_H$ and $\mu_L$.
hypotheses.latex: \mathcal{V} = H \sqcup L, \, H, L \neq \emptyset, \, \mu_H = \frac{1}{|H|} \sum_{v \in H} v, \, \mu_L = \frac{1}{|L|} \sum_{v \in L} v

hypotheses.text: Fractional sizes $f_H = |H|/k \ge f_{\min} > 0$ and $f_L = |L|/k \ge f_{\min}$, with $f_{\min} \in (0, 1/2]$.
Empirical variance $\operatorname{Var}(\mathcal{V}) \ge \kappa_{\mathrm{var}} > 0$.

conclusion.text: Squared mean difference bounded below: $(\mu_H - \mu_L)^2 \ge \frac{1}{f_H f_L} (\kappa_{\mathrm{var}} - \operatorname{Var}_{\mathrm{max}})$. If $\kappa_{\mathrm{var}} > \operatorname{Var}_{\mathrm{max}}$, then positive separation: $|\mu_H - \mu_L| \ge \frac{1}{\sqrt{f_H f_L}} \sqrt{\kappa_{\mathrm{var}} - \operatorname{Var}_{\mathrm{max}}} > 0$.

variables.name: population size
variables.description: Number of elements in the set $\mathcal{V}$.

variables.name: set of values
variables.description: Finite set of real numbers $\mathcal{V} = \{v_i\}_{i=1}^k$.

variables.name: element
variables.description: Individual value in $\mathcal{V}$.

variables.name: minimum bound
variables.description: Lower bound of the compact interval containing all $v_i$.

variables.name: maximum bound
variables.description: Upper bound of the compact interval containing all $v_i$.

variables.name: high subset
variables.description: One non-empty subset in the partition of $\mathcal{V}$.

variables.name: low subset
variables.description: The other non-empty subset in the partition of $\mathcal{V}$.

variables.name: mean of H
variables.description: Arithmetic mean of values in subset H.

variables.name: mean of L
variables.description: Arithmetic mean of values in subset L.

variables.name: fractional size of H
variables.description: Proportion $|H|/k$.

variables.name: fractional size of L
variables.description: Proportion $|L|/k$.

variables.name: minimum fraction
variables.description: Strictly positive lower bound on subset fractions.

variables.name: variance lower bound
variables.description: Strictly positive constant bounding variance from below.

variables.name: empirical variance
variables.description: Variance of the set $\mathcal{V}$.

variables.name: maximum variance
variables.description: Upper bound on variance for values in [V_min, V_max], equal to (1/4)(V_max - V_min)^2.

implicit_assumptions.text: The subsets H and L cover the entire set V (i.e., V = H union L).
The means mu_H and mu_L are well-defined since H and L are non-empty.
Empirical variance is the standard sample variance (possibly population variance, as k is total size).
The signal-to-noise condition kappa_var > Var_max ensures positive separation.

label: lem-log-gap-lower-bound
title: Lower Bound on Logarithmic Mean Gap
nl_statement: If two random variables X and Y take values in the compact interval [V_min, V_max] with V_min > 0 and their means satisfy E[X] >= E[Y] + kappa for kappa > 0, then the difference in their expected logarithms satisfies E[ln X] - E[ln Y] >= ln(1 + kappa / V_max).

hypotheses.text: X and Y are random variables taking values in the compact interval [V_min, V_max] with V_min > 0.
The means satisfy mu_X = E[X] >= mu_Y = E[Y] + kappa for some constant kappa > 0.

conclusion.text: E[ln(X)] - E[ln(Y)] >= ln(1 + kappa / V_max)

variables.name: X
variables.description: First random variable.

variables.name: Y
variables.description: Second random variable.

variables.name: V_min
variables.description: Lower bound of the support interval.

variables.name: V_max
variables.description: Upper bound of the support interval.

variables.name: mu_X
variables.description: Mean of X.

variables.name: mu_Y
variables.description: Mean of Y.

variables.name: kappa
variables.description: Positive constant for mean separation.

variables.name: E
variables.description: Expectation operator.

implicit_assumptions.text: The supports ensure X and Y are positive, allowing the logarithm to be well-defined.

steps.text: The proof uses extremal distribution theory to find the worst-case scenario.

label: lem-log-gap-upper-bound
title: Upper Bound on Logarithmic Mean Gap
nl_statement: For random variables X and Y supported on the compact interval [V_min, V_max] with V_min > 0 and means satisfying |E[X] - E[Y]| ≤ κ for some κ > 0, the absolute difference of their expected logarithms is at most ln(1 + κ / V_min).

hypotheses.text: X and Y are random variables whose values are contained in the compact interval [V_min, V_max], where V_min > 0.
Their means μ_X = E[X] and μ_Y = E[Y] satisfy |μ_X - μ_Y| ≤ κ for some constant κ > 0.

conclusion.text: |E[ln(X)] - E[ln(Y)]| ≤ ln(1 + κ / V_min)

variables.name: X
variables.description: random variable with values in [V_min, V_max]

variables.name: Y
variables.description: random variable with values in [V_min, V_max]

variables.name: μ_X
variables.description: expected value of X

variables.name: μ_Y
variables.description: expected value of Y

variables.name: V_min
variables.description: minimum value of the support interval, positive

variables.name: V_max
variables.description: maximum value of the support interval

variables.name: κ
variables.description: constant bounding the absolute difference of means

implicit_assumptions.text: The expectations E[X], E[Y], E[ln(X)], and E[ln(Y)] exist (guaranteed by compact support).

label: lem-unfit-fraction-lower-bound
title: N-Uniform Lower Bound on the Unfit Fraction
nl_statement: For a swarm of k ≥ 2 alive walkers whose fitness potential range is bounded below by the positive ε-dependent constant κ_{V,gap}(ε), the fraction of alive walkers in the unfit set U_k is bounded below by the positive N-uniform ε-dependent constant f_U(ε) = κ_{V,gap}(ε) / (2(V_{pot,max} - V_{pot,min})).

hypotheses.text: Swarm of k ≥ 2 alive walkers with fitness potential range bounded below by positive ε-dependent constant

conclusion.text: Fraction of alive walkers in unfit set U_k bounded below by positive N-uniform ε-dependent constant f_U(ε) > 0

variables.name: swarm size
variables.description: Number of alive walkers in the swarm

variables.name: epsilon
variables.description: Small positive parameter for ε-dependence

variables.name: unfit set
variables.description: Set of unfit walkers in the swarm

variables.name: max fitness potential
variables.description: Maximum fitness potential in swarm k

variables.name: min fitness potential
variables.description: Minimum fitness potential in swarm k

variables.name: fitness gap constant

The unfit set U_k is a subset of the alive walkers

label: lem-quantitative-keystone
title: The N-Uniform Quantitative Keystone Lemma
nl_statement: Under foundational axioms, there exist constants independent of N such that for any pair of swarms, the averaged weighted squared error from both swarms lower bounds the structural variance minus a constant.

hypotheses.text: Foundational axioms from Chapter 4 hold
For any pair of swarms (S_1, S_2)

conclusion.text: There exist R^2_{spread} > 0, \chi(\epsilon) > 0, g_{max}(\epsilon) \ge 0 independent of N such that the inequality holds
conclusion.latex: there exist: * a structural error threshold $R^2_{\text{spread}} > 0$, * a minimum feedback coefficient $\chi(\epsilon) > 0$, * and a constant offset $g_{\max}(\epsilon) \ge 0$, all of which may depend on $\epsilon$ but are independent of $N$, such that for any pair of swarms $(S_1, S_2)$: $$ \frac{1}{N}\sum_{i \in I_{11}} (p_{1,i} + p_{2,i})\|\Delta\delta_{x,i}\||^2 \ge \chi(\epsilon) V_{\text{struct}} - g_{\max}(\epsilon) $$

variables.name: Number of agents
variables.description: Dimension or size parameter, independent constants do not depend on it

variables.name: Error parameter
variables.description: Small error tolerance parameter

variables.name: Cloning probability swarm 1
variables.description: Cloning probability for agent i in swarm 1

variables.name: Cloning probability swarm 2
variables.description: Cloning probability for agent i in swarm 2

variables.name: Error deviation
variables.description: Delta in position deviation for agent i

variables.name: Structural variance
variables.description: Measure of structural error or spread

variables.name: Structural error threshold
variables.description: Threshold for structural spread

variables.name: Feedback coefficient
variables.description: Minimum feedback strength depending on epsilon

variables.name: Constant offset
variables.description: Maximum growth or offset term depending on epsilon

implicit_assumptions.text: Cloning pressure from one swarm suffices even if the other is in low-error state
I_{11} represents a relevant index set for high-error agents
Norms and sums are well-defined under the axioms

steps.text: Proof demonstrates that even with one high-error swarm, cloning pressure ensures the inequality.

label: lem-mean-companion-fitness-gap
title: Lower Bound on Mean Companion Fitness Gap
nl_statement: In a swarm of k ≥ 2 alive walkers with non-degenerate fitness potential range κ_{V,gap}(ε) > 0, partitioned into unfit and fit sets with positive fractions f_U and f_F, for any unfit walker i, the mean companion fitness exceeds its own fitness by at least (f_F/(k-1))(μ_F - μ_U) > 0, where μ_F - μ_U ≥ (f_U/(f_F + f_U²/f_F)) κ_{V,gap}(ε), yielding an overall lower bound Δ_min(ε, f_U, f_F, k) > 0.

equations.latex: \mu_{\text{comp},i} - V_{k,i} \geq \frac{f_F f_U}{(k-1)(f_F + f_U^2/f_F)} \kappa_{V,\text{gap}}(\epsilon) =: \Delta_{\min}(\epsilon, f_U, f_F, k)

hypotheses.text: Swarm of k ≥ 2 alive walkers with non-degenerate fitness potential range κ_{V,gap}(ε) > 0.
Unfit set U_k and fit set F_k with fractions f_U = |U_k|/k > 0, f_F = |F_k|/k > 0, f_U + f_F = 1.
Mean fitness values μ_U for U_k and μ_F for F_k.
For any walker i ∈ U_k.

conclusion.text: The mean companion fitness gap for unfit walkers is bounded below by Δ_min(ε, f_U, f_F, k) > 0.

variables.name: swarm size
variables.description: Number of alive walkers, integer ≥ 2.

variables.name: epsilon
variables.description: Parameter for fitness potential range.

variables.name: fitness gap
variables.description: Non-degenerate fitness potential range, >0.

variables.description: Set of unfit walkers.

variables.description: N-uniform lower bound on fitness gap.

implicit_assumptions.text: Walkers have assigned fitness values V_{k,i}.
Companions for walker i are the other k-1 walkers.
Fitness potential range is defined and non-degenerate for the given ε.

label: lem-unfit-cloning-pressure
title: Guaranteed Cloning Pressure on the Unfit Set
nl_statement: For a swarm of at least two alive walkers with fitness potential range bounded below by κ_{V,gap}(ε) > 0, every walker in the unfit set has total cloning probability at least the positive constant p_u(ε) > 0.

hypotheses.text: Swarm k has k ≥ 2 alive walkers.
The fitness potential range of the swarm is bounded below by κ_{V,gap}(ε) > 0.
Walker i is in the unfit set U_k.

conclusion.text: The total cloning probability p_{k,i} for walker i satisfies p_{k,i} ≥ p_u(ε) > 0, where p_u(ε) is a positive, N-uniform, ε-dependent constant.

variables.name: swarm index
variables.description: Index of the swarm.

variables.name: walker index
variables.description: Index of an unfit walker.

variables.name: error parameter
variables.description: Small positive parameter controlling approximations.

variables.name: lower bound constant
variables.description: Positive, N-uniform, ε-dependent lower bound on cloning probability.

variables.name: fitness gap
variables.description: Lower bound on the fitness potential range.

implicit_assumptions.text: The bound p_u(ε) is independent of the swarm size N.
All walkers have defined fitness potentials V_{k,j}.
The cloning distribution ℂ_i(S_k) is well-defined and supports expectation.

label: lem-variance-concentration-Hk
title: Variance Concentration in the High-Error Set
nl_statement: For a swarm in a high-error state with variance exceeding R²_var, the sum of squared deviations in the high-error set H_k(ε) is at least a fixed positive fraction c_H of the total sum of squared deviations across the swarm.

hypotheses.text: Swarm k is in a high-error state, i.e., Var_k(x) > R²_var
There exists a strictly positive N-uniform constant c_H in (0,1]

conclusion.text: The sum of squared deviations from the mean for walkers in H_k(ε) is bounded below by c_H times the total sum of squared deviations

variables.name: swarm index
variables.description: Index identifying the swarm

variables.name: high-error set
variables.description: Unified set of walkers in swarm k with errors exceeding ε

variables.name: concentration constant
variables.description: Strictly positive N-uniform constant bounding the variance fraction

variables.name: position deviation
variables.description: Squared deviation of walker i's position from the swarm mean

variables.name: swarm agents
variables.description: Set of all agents/walkers in swarm k

variables.name: variance threshold
variables.description: Threshold defining high-error state

variables.name: error parameter
variables.description: Error level parameter for defining H_k

implicit_assumptions.text: H_k(ε) is non-empty and well-defined based on error thresholds from prior geometric analysis
δ_{x,k,i} represents deviations within Euclidean space, with norm ||·||² being the squared Euclidean norm
N refers to the number of agents, and N-uniform means independent of N as N→∞
The swarm model assumes independent or structured walker positions contributing to variance

label: lem-error-concentration-target-set
title: Error Concentration in the Target Set
nl_statement: For a swarm state (S₁, S₂) in the high-error regime with V_struct > R²_spread, where k is the high-variance swarm and I_target = I_{11} ∩ U_k ∩ H_k(ε) is the critical target set, the average positional structural error in I_target is bounded below by c_err(ε) V_struct - g_err(ε).

hypotheses.text: Swarm state (S₁, S₂) is in the high-error regime
V_struct > R²_spread
k is the high-variance swarm
I_target := I_{11} ∩ U_k ∩ H_k(ε) is the critical target set

conclusion.text: The positional structural error concentrated within this target set is bounded below by a linear function of the total structural error

Sets I_{11}, U_k, H_k(ε) are non-empty and well-defined in the context

c_err(ε) and g_err(ε) are positive functions derived from prior analyses

label: lem-dead-walker-clone-prob
title: Total Cloning Probability for Dead Walkers
nl_statement: Under the Axiom of Guaranteed Revival (ε_clone · p_max < η^{α+β}), any dead walker clones with probability 1.

hypotheses.text: Axiom of Guaranteed Revival: ε_clone · p_max < η^{α+β}
i is a dead walker in state S

conclusion.text: The cloning probability for dead walker i is 1

label: lem-variance-change-decomposition
title: Variance Change Decomposition
nl_statement: The total change in positional variance decomposes into sums over alive walker contributions and status change contributions for k from 1 to 2.

conclusion.text: The total change in positional variance can be decomposed as \Delta V_{\text{Var},x} = \sum_{k=1}^{2} \left[\Delta V_{\text{Var},x}^{(k,\text{alive})} + \Delta V_{\text{Var},x}^{(k,\text{status})}\right], with the specified contributions from alive walkers and status changes.

variables.name: total-variance-change
variables.description: Total change in positional variance.

variables.name: total-walkers
variables.description: Total number of walkers.

variables.description: Index for dimensions, from 1 to 2.

variables.description: Set of alive walkers in state S_k.

variables.description: Set of dead or status-changed walkers in state S_k.

variables.description: Centered position of walker i in dimension k after cloning or update.

variables.name: state-k
variables.description: State associated with dimension k.

implicit_assumptions.text: N is the fixed total number of walkers.
Positions are in a vector space with Euclidean norm.
\delta_{x,k,i} represents centered deviations from the mean position.
The decomposition applies in the context of a walker simulation with cloning and status updates.

label: lem-keystone-contraction-alive
title: Keystone-Driven Contraction for Stably Alive Walkers
nl_statement: For walkers in the stably alive set $I_{11}$, the expected change in their contribution to variance satisfies $\mathbb{E}_{\text{clone}}\left[\sum_{i \in I_{11}} \sum_{k=1,2} \left(\|\delta'_{x,k,i}\|^2 - \|\delta_{x,k,i}\|^2\right)\right] \leq -\frac{\chi(\epsilon)}{2N} \cdot V_{\text{struct}} + \frac{g_{\max}(\epsilon)}{N} + C_{\text{pers}}$, where $\chi(\epsilon) > 0$ and $g_{\max}(\epsilon)$ are the Keystone constants, and $C_{\text{pers}}$ accounts for persisting walkers.

hypotheses.text: Walkers in the stably alive set $I_{11}$

variables.name: stably alive set
variables.description: Set of walkers alive in both swarms

variables.name: chi epsilon
variables.description: Positive Keystone constant

variables.name: g max epsilon
variables.description: Maximum Keystone constant

variables.name: structural variance
variables.description: Structural component of variance

variables.name: persistence constant
variables.description: Term accounting for persisting walkers

variables.name: number of walkers
variables.description: Total number of walkers per swarm

implicit_assumptions.text: Definitions of delta vectors and cloning process from context
Keystone constants defined in referenced lemma

nl_statement: The contribution to variance from revived dead walkers is bounded.

conclusion.text: The contribution to variance from revived dead walkers is bounded.

label: lem-fitness-gradient-boundary
title: Fitness Gradient from Boundary Proximity
nl_statement: Walkers closer to the boundary have systematically lower fitness potential than similar walkers farther from it, under the fitness evaluation pipeline.

hypotheses.text: Two walkers i and j with similar positions and velocities, except that walker i is closer to the boundary than walker j.
\varphi_{\text{barrier}}(x_i) - \varphi_{\text{barrier}}(x_j) = \Delta_{\text{barrier}} > 0

conclusion.text: Under the fitness evaluation pipeline, walker i has systematically lower fitness potential

variables.name: barrier potential
variables.description: Potential function measuring proximity to boundary

variables.name: barrier difference
variables.description: Difference in barrier potential between i and j

variables.name: fitness potential i
variables.description: Fitness potential for walker i

variables.name: fitness potential j
variables.description: Fitness potential for walker j

variables.name: penalty function
variables.description: Function applying penalty based on barrier difference

implicit_assumptions.text: Walkers i and j have similar positions and velocities apart from boundary proximity
Fitness evaluation pipeline integrates barrier proximity into fitness calculation as per Chapter 5
f is a positive decreasing function of \Delta_{\text{barrier}}

label: lem-boundary-enhanced-cloning
title: Enhanced Cloning Probability Near Boundary
nl_statement: For any walker i in the boundary-exposed set \mathcal{E}_{\text{boundary}}(S), its cloning probability p_i satisfies p_i \geq p_{\text{boundary}}(\phi_{\text{thresh}}) > 0.

variables.description: Index of a walker in the boundary-exposed set

label: lem-barrier-reduction-cloning
title: Expected Barrier Reduction for Cloned Walker
nl_statement: When a boundary-exposed walker $i$ clones, the expected barrier penalty after cloning is at most the expected barrier penalty of its companion plus $C_{\text{jitter}} = O(\sigma_x^2)$. Furthermore, if the companion is from the safe interior, the expected barrier penalty is at most $C_{\text{jitter}}$.

hypotheses.text: a boundary-exposed walker $i$ clones
the companion $c_i$ is from the safe interior $\mathcal{I}_{\text{safe}}$ (for the second bound)

variables.name: walker index
variables.description: Index of the boundary-exposed walker that clones

variables.name: cloned walker position
variables.description: Position of the cloned walker after cloning

variables.name: barrier penalty function
variables.description: Function measuring the barrier penalty at a position

variables.name: companion position
variables.description: Position of the companion walker used in cloning

variables.name: companion index
variables.description: Index of the companion walker

variables.name: jitter constant
variables.description: Constant bounding the jitter effect, equal to O(\sigma_x^2)

variables.name: position jitter standard deviation
variables.description: Standard deviation of the position jitter in cloning

variables.name: safe interior set
variables.description: Set of safe interior positions or walkers

implicit_assumptions.text: Cloning involves selecting a companion walker and adding position jitter.
The barrier function \varphi_{\text{barrier}} is non-negative and penalizes boundary proximity.
Walkers are positioned in a space with defined boundaries and safe interior.
